DOC.HEAD: New Trial Ordered for Man Alleging Police Brutality
Eds: Note language in 5th graf may offend some readers.
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court has overturned the murder conviction of a man who said police beat him and put a plastic bag over his head to make him confess. The court said that when a defendant is injured in custody, the prosecution must show by ``clear and convincing evidence that the injuries were not inflicted as a means of producing the confession.'' A three-judge panel of the 1st District Illinois Court of Appeals, ruling Thursday, ordered a new trial for Gregory Banks. Banks testified that while police interrogated him in 1983, Sgt. John Byrne hit him with a flashlight while his hands were handcuffed behind his back and stuck a pistol in his mouth, threatening to shoot. Banks also said Sgt. Peter Dignan, then a detective, said ``we have something for niggers,'' then put a plastic bag over his head for more than a minute while Detective Charles Grunhard kicked him. Banks said that when Dignan put the bag over his head again about 10 minutes later, he confessed. Dignan testified he tackled Banks when he tried to escape while handcuffed. But the appellate court cited testimony from a doctor at Cook County Hospital that Banks' injuries weren't of a type that would be inflicted in a tackle. Dignan said people convicted of murder often claim they were brutalized, and called the allegation that police used a plastic bag ridiculous. ``Banks is a huge fellow, and he's guilty as sin,'' Dignan said. ``He did flee, and I tackled him. I got an elbow in the face and I punched back.'' Banks was convicted in 1984 of robbing and killing Leon Barkan in a drug-related dispute. Cook County Circuit Judge Robert L. Sklodowski sentenced him to 50 years in prison. Sklowodski said that in making his ruling, he had to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses. He said he took into account the fact that Banks was appearing in repeat offender's court, were defendents have two previous felony convictions.
